content: Kudos to the Texas state government on being the highest ranked state in placing Public Records online. Now, after reading the article below, do you think these type of records should be online? I cannot see anything wrong in that but I am curious. quote: Online records: Survey finds many states lagging By DAVID CRARY, AP National Writer ... The surveyed categories included school test scores, financial disclosures, audit reports, transportation projects, fraudulent registration of business names, disciplinary actions against lawyers and physicians, and inspection reports for hospitals, nursing homes, child care centers, bridges, school buildings and school buses. The information least likely to be found online were death certificates, found on the Web sites of only five states, and gas pump overcharge records, available online in eight. Also infrequently posted online were schools building inspections and safety ratings, which are posted by only nine states, and school bus inspection reports, which 13 states posted. "People should be able to find inspection records for their schools online," said David Cuillier, FOI Committee chairman for the Society of Professional Journalists. "And the government shouldn't be charging people for death certificates and other records." Information found most often online were statewide school test scores, available in all states, and Department of Transportation projects, posted in 48 states. Campaign finance data and disciplinary actions against physicians were available in 47 states. The only state found to provide information online in all 20 categories was Texas. New Jersey was second with 18, North Carolina third with 17. The state with the sparsest information online was Mississippi. It posted only DOT projects, fictitious business registrations, school test scores and campaign finance data. Though it did post some information about hospitals and nursing homes, surveyors said these were perfunctory lists, not inspection reports. Mississippi's low ranking is linked both to tight budgets in many state agencies and to the state's relative lack of home computers. It ranks near the bottom in percentage of households with Internet access, providing some agencies with a rationale for not investing more funds in online initiatives... >http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090315/ap_on_re_us/sunshine_online_access>

New Jersey was second with 18, North Carolina third with 17. The state with the sparsest information online was Mississippi. It posted only DOT projects, fictitious business registrations, school test scores and campaign finance data. Though it did post some information about hospitals and nursing homes, surveyors said these were perfunctory lists, not inspection reports. Mississippi's low ranking is linked both to tight budgets in many state agencies and to the state's relative lack of home computers. It ranks near the bottom in percentage of households with Internet access, providing some agencies with a rationale for not investing more funds in online initiatives... >http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090315/ap_on_re_us/sunshine_online_access>

title: Attaboy Texas! Kudos to you!

content: I dont see a problem here. Most newspapers are online now and most of that information is public record. Not a big fan of students indvidual test scores online, though that is not the case here.
reply: I dont see a problem here. Most newspapers are online now and most of that information is public record. Not a big fan of students indvidual test scores online, though that is not the case here.
title: Attaboy Texas! Kudos to you!

content: Yes, I love it. In a way it keeps everybody honest. I remember once I had to pay $1100 one year in property taxes on a $214.000 home. My brother in law was only paying $800.00 a month on a $650.000 home. After looking it up on the internet I wrote an anomalous letter to the tax office and the following year he was crying because he had to pay so much more. I LMAO.

The surveyed categories included school test scores, financial disclosures, audit reports, transportation projects, fraudulent registration of business names, disciplinary actions against lawyers and physicians, and inspection reports for hospitals, nursing homes, child care centers, bridges, school buildings and school buses. The information least likely to be found online were death certificates, found on the Web sites of only five states, and gas pump overcharge records, available online in eight. Also infrequently posted online were schools building inspections and safety ratings, which are posted by only nine states, and school bus inspection reports, which 13 states posted. "People should be able to find inspection records for their schools online," said David Cuillier, FOI Committee chairman for the Society of Professional Journalists. "And the government shouldn't be charging people for death certificates and other records." Information found most often online were statewide school test scores, available in all states, and Department of Transportation projects, posted in 48 states. Campaign finance data and disciplinary actions against physicians were available in 47 states. The only state found to provide information online in all 20 categories was Texas. It ranks near the bottom in percentage of households with Internet access, providing some agencies with a rationale for not investing more funds in online initiatives... >http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090315/ap_on_re_us/sunshine_online_access> I don't see a problem as long as it is "public record." You can also see if your teacher is actually certified to teach. School reports based on varying criteria is available at a site called greatschools (dot) com. Disciplinary actions against doctors, lawyers, dentists is helpful too. Also the lists of child molesters when they move into a community is available on-line (as well as an immediate alert is sent to nearby school districts which disseminate the information to parents). Individual student test scores can not be posted. "They love our milk and honey but they preach about some other way of living When you’re running down my country, Hoss you’re walking on the fighting side of me" - - Merle Haggard

content: Our county clerk has been pro-active putting public records on line. However she was up for re-election last November. Now here is the joke. A lib/socialist raised a stink about public records posted on line that contained social security numbers. Ready for this? That lib/socialist has a company that sells a software product to redact SSN info from on line postings. Come to find out the county was using this lib/socialist's software product. Seems it wasn't working as well as he claimed it would when he sold it to the county.
